For each day of #BlackHistoryMonth we will be featuring an African-American history-maker from Maryland. Today’s entry is Thurgood Marshall, the first African-American to serve on the Supreme Court. Born in Baltimore in 1908, Marshall earned his undergraduate degree from Lincoln University in Pennsylvania and later obtained a law degree from Howard University Law School in Washington. Marshall became chief counsel for the NAACP in 1938 and throughout his distinguished career Marshall helped advance many decisions that led to the expansion of civil rights. In 1954, Marshall successfully argued before the Supreme Court in the historic Brown vs. Board of Education case. Overall, Marshall won 29 of the 32 cases he argued before the Supreme Court. In 1967, President Lyndon B. Johnson nominated Marshall for the Supreme Court, where he served until 1991.

Happy Black History Month! February is a time to recognize and reflect upon the achievements and contributions of African-Americans. The barriers that so many struggled to overcome should be an inspiration to us in the present and a call to continue to work for equality and justice. One of the wonderful things about Maryland is our diversity and our state has been home to some of our nation’s most influential African-Americans and for each day of #BlackHistoryMonth we will be highlighting a history-making Marylander on Facebook.

Today’s entry is Henry Blair an inventor and one of the first African-Americans to receive a patent in the United States. Blair was born in Glen Ross, Maryland in 1807. In 1834, Blair received his first patent for a corn planter, a wheel-driven device that allowed farmers to plant more corn using less labor in a shorter period of time. (see image below) The planter looked much like a wheelbarrow, with a compartment included to hold seeds and rakes which dragged behind to cover the soil. Newspaper accounts at the time claimed that the device would combine the labor of eight people into one device. Two years later, Blair received his second patent, this time for a cotton planter. Blair died in 1860.

Today’s #BlackHistoryMonth entry is James Pennington, a minister, writer and abolitionist. Born a slave on the Eastern Shore in 1807, Pennington was eventually moved to a farm near Hagerstown. At the age of 19, Pennington escaped, eventually landing in Pennsylvania and then later moving to New York. As a young man he made his way to New York, where he worked diligently to receive an education, paying for tutors out of his earnings. Pennington began attending classes at Yale Divinity School in the 1830s, becoming the first black student to study at Yale, although he was not allowed to speak in class or borrow books from the library. Pennington later became a prominent minister, public speaker and abolitionist, speaking across the United States and United Kingdom. In 1841, he wrote one of the first histories of African-Americans and published a memoir, The Fugitive Blacksmith. Pennington wrote about the difficult life endured by slaves and disputed pro-slavery rhetoric. Pennington’s story was popular and went through three editions in two years. In the late 1840s he became deeply involved in the anti-slavery movement and was a delegate to the 1843 Anti-Slavery Convention in London. During the Civil War, Pennington helped recruit black troops to serve in the Union Army. He died in 1870.

For each day of #BlackHistoryMonth we're highlighting a history-maker from Maryland. Today's entry is Frederick Douglass, who has made his way into the news recently. Douglass was born a slave in 1818 in Talbot County. Douglass learned to read and write at a young age, teaching other slaves to do the same. Douglass often said, “Knowledge is the pathway from slavery to freedom.” Douglass met Anne Murray, a free woman, in 1837. She motivated him to escape slavery in 1838, eventually taking a train north to freedom. After gaining his freedom, Douglass began to read The Liberator, a weekly journal written by William Lloyd Garrison. The Liberator inspired Douglass to get more involved in the abolitionist movement. He gave impassioned speeches across the country, detailing his life story and rousing many Americans to take action. In 1845, Douglass published one of his most widely read and influential works, “Narrative of the Life of Frederick Douglass, an American Slave.” His autobiography immediately became a bestseller, capturing the brutality of slavery in America. Douglass began publishing his first abolitionist newspaper, The North Star, with the motto “Right is of no Sex – Truth is of no Color – God is the Father of us all, and we are all brethren.” Douglass not only fought for emancipation, but for women’s suffrage. He attended the 1848 Seneca Falls Convention, where he was a major influence passing a resolution asking for women’s suffrage. Douglass continued to fight for civil rights and suffrage throughout the Civil War and Reconstruction periods. By the time of his death in 1895, Douglass was known around the world as a champion for justice, freedom, and equality.

Today’s Black History Month entry is Josiah Henson, an author, abolitionist, and minister, who was born in 1789 in Charles County.  Born into slavery, as an adult Josiah worked in the fields for a man named Isaac Riley, on his farm in Montgomery County in what is now in North Bethesda.  He quickly gained the favor of Riley and became the supervisor of his master’s farm.  After saving up $350, Josiah Henson attempted to buy his freedom from Riley with a promise of an extra $100.  Riley added an extra zero to the paper, changing the fee to $1000 and cheated Josiah out of his freedom and money. Josiah then escaped with his family to Canada, where he founded a settlement for escaped slaves. The Dawn settlement grew to 500 people at its peak, and they exported black walnut lumber to the United States and Britain. Henson's autobiography, The Life of Josiah Henson, Formerly a Slave, Now an Inhabitant of Canada, as Narrated by Himself is believed to have inspired the title character of Harriet Beecher Stowe's Uncle Tom's Cabin. Henson was the first black man to be featured on a Canadian stamp.  He died in Canada on May 5th, 1883 at the age of 93.

For each day of #BlackHistoryMonth we're celebrating African-American leaders from Maryland. Today’s profile is explorer Matthew Henson, who made history planting the American flag at the North Pole in 1909. Henson’s journey began in Maryland in 1866, when he was born in Charles County. Both of Henson’s parents died by the time he was nine and by age 12, Henson was working in Baltimore. In 1887, he met the explorer Robert Peary and joined Peary’s crew on his 1890 expedition to Greenland. For the next twenty years, Henson spent much of his time in the Arctic, developing his skills driving sleds and learning the Inuit language. In 1906, Peary’s expedition reached the furthest point north of any expedition to date. Three years later, in 1909, Henson was part of a six-man expedition to the North Pole, the only American to join Peary on the trip. Traveling ahead of Peary on April 6 1909, Henson approached the Pole. After walking back to join Peary, Henson told him, “I think I'm the first man to sit on top of the world.” Henson is credited as Co-Discoverer of the North Pole. In 1912, Henson published his memoirs. Henson was admitted to the prestigious Explorers Club in New York and honored by Presidents Truman and Eisenhower before he died in 1955. Henson’s tomb reads, “The lure of the Arctic is tugging at my heart. To me the trail is calling. The old trail. The trail that is always new.” The Matthew Henson Trail and Matthew Henson State Park in Montgomery County are named for him.

Today’s #BlackHistoryMonth entry is Clarence Muse, an actor, screenwriter, director and composer born in Baltimore on October 14th, 1889.  Muse studied at Dickinson College, in Carlisle, Pennsylvania where he received his degree in international law in 1911.  After moving to Hollywood in 1929, Muse joined the cast of the first all-African American movie, Hearts in Dixie.  In 1943, Muse became the first African American Broadway director and was the first African American to be the lead “star” in a film with his role in Broken Earth (1936), which focused on the hardships faced by black farmers in the South.  He co-authored the script for Way Down South (1939) with Langston Hughes and was the co-writer of many notable songs, including “When It’s Sleepy Time Down South”, which became one of the signature songs of Louis Armstrong.  Muse’s acting career spanned more than six decades and he appeared in over 150 movies. In 1973 he was inducted into the Black Filmmakers Hall of Fame. He received an honorary doctor of humanities degree from Bishop College, Texas in 1972. Muse died in 1979, the year he appeared in his final film.

Today’s #BlackHistoryMonth entry is Benjamin Banneker, an African-American scientist, surveyor, author and farmer, born in Baltimore County in 1731. Banneker was largely self-educated in astronomy and in mathematics. He became an active writer of almanacs and was appointed by President George Washington to the District of Columbia Commission. His early accomplishments included constructing a wooden clock and accurately forecasting eclipses. Banneker's talents eventually came to the attention of the Ellicott brothers, industrialists in the Baltimore area. In 1791, Banneker teamed up with Major Andrew Ellicott, an American surveyor, to map the new national capital. During Thomas Jefferson's tenure as Secretary of State, Banneker wrote Jefferson and attacked his position on slavery and urged him to recognize that “one Universal Father…afforded us all the same sensations and endowed us all with the same faculties.” Banneker's outspokenness with regard to the issue of slavery earned him the widespread support of the abolitionist societies in Maryland and Pennsylvania, both of which helped him publish his almanac. Banneker died in Baltimore in 1806.

Today’s Maryland Black History Month feature is Joshua Johnson, who is considered the first African-American to make a living as a painter in the United States. Johnson was born a slave around 1763. George Johnson purchased Joshua and acknowledged Joshua as his son when Joshua was 19. Joshua received his freedom in 1782 and devoted his life to painting. There are no records of Johnson receiving educational or creative training. We do know that as of 1796, he advertised himself as a portrait painter and a limner, a painter of ornamental decoration. Johnson painted many elite Baltimoreans, such as judicial officers, captains, and wealthy plantation owners. Noticeably, Johnson sometimes painted multi-figure family group portraits, a very rare practice during this period in American history. Financially successful as an artist, records indicate that Johnson was a property owner in Montgomery, Frederick and Anne Arundel County later in live. Johnson would have been able to make extra money painting chairs.  Johnson died around 1824, leaving his mark on America as one of the original prominent self-taught artists. A number of his works are now part of the Smithsonian American Art Museum.

For each day of #BlackHistoryMonth we're celebrating history-makers from Maryland. Today we remember Frances Harper, a Baltimore-born abolitionist, poet and author. Harper was born in 1825 to free parents, but was raised by her aunt and uncle. She was exposed to literature and prose throughout her schooling at the Academy for Negro Youth, inspiring her to write poetry from a young age. Harper’s poetry career formally began in 1845 with the release of her first collection, Forest Leaves. After teaching at Union Seminary, a school that was ran by abolitionist John Brown, Harper focused her writing talents towards the abolitionist movement.  In addition to joining the anti-slavery lecture circuit, Harper wrote renowned pieces including “Bury Me in a Free Land” and “Sketches of Southern Life.” These poems brought to life the themes and stories of the abolitionist movement.  “Bury Me in a Free Land” begins, “Make me a grave where’er you will,/ In a lowly plain, or a lofty hill;/ Make it among earth’s humblest graves,/ But not in a land where men are slaves.” Harper further made history as the first African-American woman to publish a short story. Along with Harriet Tubman, Ida B. Wells and other female abolitionists, Harper helped found a national association for African-American women. Harper passed away in 1911.

Today’s Black History Month feature is Esther McCready, a trailblazer and civil rights leader who desegregated the University of Maryland’s Nursing School by suing for her admission. Born in 1931 in Baltimore, McCready knew she wanted to be a nurse from a young age. She was particularly inspired by the care she received at Johns Hopkins Hospital’s pediatric center and her work as a nursing aide at Sinai Hospital. She graduated with honors from Dunbar High School, one of only two East Baltimore high schools accepting African-American students at the time. Though she was an entirely qualified candidate, the school denied her admission. With the help of NAACP leaders Charles Hamilton Houston, Donald Gains Murray, and Thurgood Marshall, she successfully sued for her right to attend the school. McCready’s persistence to get the best education possible desegregated University of Maryland’s Nursing School, and paved the way for other departments at the university to follow suit. Her case, was decided on April 14th, 1950. McCready dedicated her life to nursing, working at the Druid Health Center, Cornell Medical Center, and Harlem Hospital. She also served as Head Nurse at the Morgan State University. McCready is proudly recognized as a member of the Maryland Women’s Hall of Fame.

Today’s Black History Month feature is Lord Nickens. The son of a former slave, Nickens was born in 1913 and his family moved to Frederick when he was a child. At age six, after mistakenly entering a white-only bathroom at a train station, Nickens was kicked by a conductor. Nickens served in the Army in World War II, where he rose to the rank of Sergeant Major. After the war, Nickens returned to Frederick and became a lab technician at Fort Detrick. In Frederick, Nickens organized boycotts of segregated businesses and founded the Frederick Community Action Agency (FCAA). After the 1954 Brown v. Board decision, Nickens helped lead the effort to integrate Frederick High School. Nickens would later serve for 22 years as President of the Frederick County NAACP. Through his organizing he also helped integrate neighborhoods in Frederick, expanding housing opportunities. Nickens was a frequent target of the KKK, but persisted in his actions. In 2013, Nickens passed away at the age of 99.

Today’s Black History Month entry is William O. Wilson, the first resident of Washington County to receive the Medal of Honor, the nation’s highest military award. Wilson was born September 16, 1867 in Hagerstown. In 1889, Wilson enlisted in the 9th Calvary, popularly known as the Buffalo Soldiers. When Wilson’s unit was surrounded by hostile forces in 1890, scouts refused to risk their lives to send a message for assistance. However, Wilson volunteered to break out of the blockade to deliver a message for help, helping to turn the tide of battle. In 1891, Wilson was awarded the Medal of Honor, for “qualities of the most conspicuous bravery and gallantry.”  In 1898, Wilson returned to Hagerstown and began his civilian life. In Hagerstown, Wilson worked as a carpenter and upholsterer. In 1988, a traffic triangle was named for him and a marker placed there. In 1997, the Veterans Administration placed a military marker at his grave. A feature on Wilson from WHAG TV is linked below.

For each day of #BlackHistoryMonth we’re celebrating African-Americans from Maryland. Today’s profile is Civil War soldier Eli Truly of Garrett County. Truly was born in Virginia in 1814 and prior to his enlistment in the Union Army he was employed in Washington as a laborer. During the war Truly was a member of the 31st Regiment. The 31st Regiment was organized in New York and was active during the later years of the war. Truly’s regiment was part of the Battle of Cold Harbor, the siege of Richmond and the Appomattox Campaign and was on-site during the surrender of General Robert E. Lee at Appomattox Court House.  After the war, Truly relocated to Garrett County, where he lived until his death in 1877. Truly is one of two black Union soldiers buried in the Oakland Cemetery.

Today’s Maryland #BlackHistoryMonth feature is Harriet Tubman. Born into slavery in Dorchester County in 1822, Tubman was a pivotal figure in the Underground Railroad. As a child Tubman was beaten, suffering from severe head injuries that would lead to seizures and headaches throughout her life. In 1850, concerned about her family, Tubman escaped slavery and moved to Philadelphia.  By 1851 she was working to help others gain their freedom. Over the course of a decade she made repeated trips into slave-holding areas, leading over 60 out of slavery. Tubman developed keen skills in subterfuge, covert travel and disguise to escape capture. One of her last trips was to retrieve her parents, who had become free but were still under threat of arrest for aiding others. According to Tubman, throughout her many years on the railroad, she never lost a “passenger.” Tubman was a strong supporter of the Union during the Civil War and helped lead an armed assault and the rescue of hundreds of slaves in South Carolina. In later years, Tubman became an advocate for women’s suffrage. To mark the centennial of Tubman’s death in 2013, President Obama signed into law the creation of the Harriet Tubman Monument in Cambridge, Maryland.

Today’s #BlackHistoryMonth feature is Dr. N. Louise Young, the first African-American woman to practice medicine in Maryland. She earned her undergraduate degree at Howard University in 1927 and her medical degree from the Howard University School of Medicine in 1930. She was a Baltimore native and she specialized in gynecology and obstetrics. In 1932, she opened up her own practice above her father’s drug store, Young’s Pharmacy in Druid Hill Avenue. Dr. Young was also the women’s physician at Morgan State College, staff physician at the Maryland Training School for Girls, and girls’ physician at Frederick Douglass High School. During the course of her career Dr. Young delivered thousands of babies and friends said aid Dr. Young once said the “most wonderful thing in the world was to deliver a healthy baby, and to see the expression on the mother's face and the father's face.” She retired in 1984, having practiced medicine for 52 years. She died on September 22, 1997 at the age of 90.

Today’s Maryland #BlackHistoryMonth feature is John W. Wormack Sr. of Cumberland. Wormack was born in 1905 and worked on the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad for many years while remaining active in many civic and community service organizations throughout Cumberland. Wormack would eventually become the first African-American to seek political office in the City of Cumberland. He was elected to the position of Commissioner of Streets and Public Property from 1974 to 1978. In addition, to his time in office Wormack served the City of Cumberland for over eleven years as both a member and Chairman of the Community Relations Commission. Wormack ran for City Council in 1982. While his candidacy was unsuccessful, his example continues to inspire people to get involved in their local community. For all of his achievements, the City of Cumberland designated June 9, 1989 as, "John W. Wormack, Sr. Day."

In commemoration of #BlackHistoryMonth, today we are celebrating John and Carl Murphy, a father and son pair who were instrumental in the rise of the Baltimore Afro-American newspaper, the longest running African-American family owned newspaper in the United States. Born in Baltimore in 1841, John Murphy spent his early life as a slave, eventually serving in the Union Army during the Civil War. He founded the Afro-American in 1892. Carl Murphy was born in Baltimore in 1889. He received his Bachelor’s degree from Howard University and taught German at the university after graduation. He inherited the Afro-American from his father in 1922, serving as the paper’s publisher and chief editor for 49 years. Under his guidance, the Afro-American increased its distribution substantially, producing a national edition and local editions in Philadelphia, Newark, Richmond and more. The Afro-American also covered African American soldiers fighting in WWII by reporting from the battleground and played a key role in amplifying the Civil Rights movement. Carl Murphy further served as Chairman of the Legal Defense Committee of the NAACP, working towards desegregating schools, from the University of Maryland’s David Murray case in 1935 to Brown v Board of Education in 1954. John Murphy once said, "I measure a newspaper not in building, equipment and employees. Those are the trimmings. Today’s Maryland Black History Month feature is Reverend William J. Watkins, an African-American religious leader, abolitionist, and educator. Born in Baltimore around 1803, Watkins was known best for operating his own school, the Watkins Academy. Watkins became a teacher at age 19 and based his school on the belief that education was the key to prosperity to his students. Watkins served as minister of the Sharp Street A.M.E. Church, practiced medicine and was the founder of a local literary society. During his lifetime Watkins also produced abolitionist literature and worked as a journalist in Frederick Douglas’ antislavery North Star periodical.  Later in life Watkins moved to Canada where he continued his work as an abolitionist until he died in 1858.

Today’s Maryland #BlackHistoryMonth entry is Parren Mitchell, the first African-American elected to Congress from Maryland. Born in Baltimore, Mitchell served in World War II, receiving a Purple Heart for his service in Italy. He earned his bachelor’s degree from Morgan State University and In 1950 Mitchell sued the University of Maryland for the right to attend graduate school in College Park and won admission. Mitchell later became a professor of sociology and assistant director of the Urban Studies Institute at Morgan State. In 1970, Mitchell was elected to represent Maryland’s 7th District in the House of Representatives. He was the first black legislator elected to a state south of the Mason-Dixon Line since 1898. Mitchell would serve in the House until 1987, leading the Congressional Black Caucus and became the first African-American to chair the Small Business Committee, where he was a staunch advocate for minority-owned businesses.

Today’s Maryland #BlackHistoryMonth feature is baseball player Clarence Smith. Born in 1895, Smith joined the Cumberland Cubs in 1915. Known as “Cannonball” for his blazing fastballs, Smith quickly made a name for himself. At the time, baseball teams were segregated along racial lines. Nevertheless Smith pursued his passion, delivering breathtaking performances and nail-biting pitcher’s duels. Smith once struck out 20 players in one game against the Harrisburg Giants. He retired from the sport in 1925 and worked several jobs in Cumberland. In 1946, Smith became the manager of the all-black Fulton Myers Post 153 American Legion ball club in the Interstate Baseball League. Smith died in Cumberland in 1969.

Today’s entry is teacher and civil rights activist Juanita Jackson Mitchell who was the first African-American woman to practice law in Maryland. Mitchell was born in 1913 in Arkansas. After moving to Maryland, Mitchell taught in the Baltimore public school system. In 1950, she became the first African-American woman to graduate from the University of Maryland School of Law. Mitchell later became the special assistant to the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP) National Secretary Walter White. She became the first national director of the NAACP Youth and College Division. Mitchell worked to revive the NAACP Baltimore branch and reach out to large numbers in the Baltimore area. As a lawyer, she took on civil rights issues and fought against discrimination. She helped to make Maryland the first state south of the Mason-Dixon line to integrate its school system after the 1954 Supreme Court decision in Brown versus Board of Education. She organized voter registration drives for decades in Baltimore. Mitchell died in Baltimore in 1992. Her sons Michael and Clarence followed in her footsteps and became Maryland State Senators.

Today’s Maryland #BlackHistoryMonth feature is Robert Curbeam, NASA astronaut. Born in Baltimore, Curbeam graduated from Woodlawn High School and earned a B.S. in aerospace engineering from the United States Naval Academy and two graduate degrees from the Naval Postgraduate School. Curbeam began Naval Flight Officer training in 1984 and in 1986, he reported to Fighter Squadron 11 and made overseas deployments to the Mediterranean, Caribbean, Arctic and Indian Oceans. Curbeam was selected by NASA in December 1994. As an astronaut, Curbeam participated in three space flights and logged over 901 hours in space. Curbeam currently holds the record for the most spacewalks during a single spaceflight. Curbeam served as a spacecraft communicator responsible for relaying all voice communication between Mission Control and crews aboard the Space Shuttle and International Space Station and was responsible for representing the crew office in the design, training and operation of on orbit experiments, and Safety Branch Chief for the astronaut office. Curbeam’s last spaceflight was in 2006, a mission to the International Space Station that lasted 12 days, 20 hours and 45 minutes. Curbeam now works in the private sector. In a 2016 interview with WGNO TV, Curbeam said, “I tell everybody to imagine the best picture from space you've seen. It’s a hundred times more beautiful … It is absolutely wonderful.”

Today’s Black History Month entry is Clifton Reginald Wharton, Sr., an African-American diplomat who was born in 1899 in Baltimore. Wharton received a law degree from Boston University and was the first African-American to earn a MA degree in international affairs from Johns Hopkins University. Wharton became the first African-American to rise to the rank of Ambassador through the Foreign Service and the first African-American Foreign Service Officer to be chief of a diplomatic mission.  By 1958, Wharton was the highest ranking African-American in the Foreign Service and was appointed the U.S. Minister to Romania. From 1961 to 1964, Wharton served as the US Ambassador to Norway. President Kennedy named Wharton the U.S. Representative to NATO and a delegate to the United Nations. Wharton retired in 1964 and died in 1990 in Arizona.

Today’s Black History Month feature is, Clarence M. Mitchell Jr., civil rights leader. Mitchell was born on March 8, 1911 in Baltimore. As a young man Mitchell started his career writing for the Baltimore Afro-American newspaper, where he covered the infamous Scottsboro case and the lynching of Matthew Williams. These events led him to pursue racial justice. In 1947 he began working for the NAACP and would eventually become one of their leading representatives in Washington.  Mitchell was instrumental in building support for landmark civil rights legislation such as the 1964 Civil Rights Act, the Voting Rights Act, and the Fair Housing Act. Mitchell was so effective that he was nicknamed the “101st Senator.” After the assassination of Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. in 1968, Mitchell was one of the African-American leaders who met with President Johnson. On June 9, 1980 President Carter awarded Mitchell the Presidential Medal of Freedom, the highest civilian honor in the United States, for his distinguished service to the country and the advancement of equal rights. Later in life he wrote a weekly column for the Baltimore Sun. The Mitchell Building at the University of Maryland is named for him. His brother Parren was the first African-American elected to Congress from Maryland.

Today’s Black History Month entry is Henry Highland Garnet, a passionate advocate for the abolition of slavery who made history as the first African-American to speak in the U.S. House of Representatives. Born a slave in Maryland in 1818, Garnet eventually gained his freedom and became a Presbyterian minister in New York. In the decades before the Civil War, Garnet became a leading abolitionist, traveling as far as Scotland to speak out against slavery. Garnet became a member of the American Anti-Slavery Society and helped recruit African-Americans to join the Union Army when the Civil War broke out. For his efforts, Garnet was attacked by a mob in 1863, but eluded their capture. In 1865, President Lincoln invited Garnet to speak in the House chamber in the U.S. Capitol to commemorate the passage of the 13th Amendment, which ended slavery. In his historic remarks, Garnet challenged Congress to “Emancipate, Enfranchise, and to Educate.” Years later, Garnet was appointed U.S. Minister to Liberia, where he died in 1881.

For today's Maryland Black History Month post, we feature Jacob Wheaton, widely remembered as the first African-American to vote in Maryland. In 2013, a renovated grave marker for Wheaton was laid.

We hope that you've enjoyed our series on African-American leaders from Maryland. Today’s Maryland Black History Month highlight is Reginald F. Lewis (1942-1993) the first African-American to create a billion dollar company. Lewis was born in Baltimore and raised in a middle-class neighborhood. After attending Virginia State College on a football scholarship, he graduated in 1965 with a degree in economics and went on to attend Harvard Law School. After fifteen years as a corporate lawyer, Lewis purchased the McCall Pattern Company, reconstructed its business model and led the company to its most profitable year ever. In 1987, Lewis bought Beatrice International Foods, renamed it TLC Beatrice International and, with peak sales of $2.2 billion, transformed it into the largest African-American owned and managed business in the United States. Lewis was also known for his work as a philanthropist. His first major grant was a $1 million dollar donation to Howard University. In 1992, he contributed $3 million to Harvard Law School, the largest ever donation in the school’s history. In response, Harvard created the first major facility on their campus named in honor of an African-American, the Reginald F. Lewis International Law Center. Among a variety of programs, the grant supports education programs for minority students. During his life, Lewis supported new efforts to celebrate African-American culture. His foundation was instrumental in the creation of the Reginald F. Lewis Museum of Maryland African American History & Culture in Baltimore.
